You may be moving the earth and sky to get what they ask of you done and not get an inch of gratefulness or thank you- in fact they just move the bar and make you feel like you didnt reach it, change direction and not use your work at all that you stayed up all day and night doing to meet an out of the blue impossible deadline. Fear based leadership for this team which feels like worker bees holding up the team. You do make great friends as you share each others pain and hold each other up. I have no time to grow in my career at all as every second is taken up by work. 0 work life balance and actually bring home work and the stress, anxiety, and abuse with me.

For example, incredibly generous time off, instead of "unlimited PTO". Territories are not unusually large for field teams and they are growing their patient support options through acquisitions of patient support hubs. The different teams work hard to make sure folks in different functions are supported. Such as national contracts are in place quickly and we feel the results downstream on a local level, or we can reach out to people in different functions to have candid conversations about what isn't happening that we've been told to expect. There's a great amount of partnership that's possible if you're willing to reach out. That part of the company culture is great to be a part of.
cons_text: While the company has made huge strides by purchasing the PSC (Patient Service Center) and integrating the company's personnel as J&J employees, they are a sub par hub with training lapses. Many of the interactions I have with them lack accountability and professionalism. I think this hub would benefit from a different model and increased incentivization to perform at a higher level for patients. I worry what patients experience when relying on the PSC for information regarding their treatments and I often do not feel our hub counterparts are genuinely our partners who understand the responsibility they have to produce results for patients.

cons_text: Where to begin... GSK as a company is an after thought among larger industry players, their pipeline is weak, they haven't experienced significant growth in decades, and recent acquisitions suggest poor purchases and capital allocation. Structurally, there is significant bureaucracy in this company that is a death knell to innovation and efficiencies, there are many layers of middle management with countless directors, associate managers, and other fancy sounding titles. I worked at for this company for many years and I still don't know what many of these positions did and many seemed either redundant or highly specialized. When it comes to hiring individuals, there seems to be an incredible lack of attention on meaningful skill and capabilities, and more emphasis on diversity and value... which frankly is so hypocritical because this company holds a record for one the largest fines in US history related to their marketing practices and integrity. Competitors seem to be bounding ahead and no one in the company that has any kind of important role seems to offer a strategy or solution. It becomes very tiresome to listen to these people talk, but never do. If you want an okay salary and you can be easily convinced of "great things to come", by all means give this company a go, but make sure to bring you Excedrin because you will quickly start wondering how any of the people running this circus got their roles. If you do happen to end up working for this company, you will probably have two possible career paths. The most likely is a string of rejections, failed attempts, and being told how important you are without ever advancing. The less likely path is that the cohort of dunderheads see themselves in you, salute your perceived greatness, and usher you into their special club of world-changing disrupters that benefit from titles, but not brains. This company is so built on a foundation of nonsense that it will either implode or languish against its peers for future decades. If you end up working here, it will likely be just a job and not a career. You have yourself to blame if you choose to work here.

pros_text: Mayo Clinic is deeply committed to patient care. Everyone working here prioritizes the needs of the patient above all else. Team members across different roles treat each other with respect and professionalism. Staff parking is provided free of charge onsite. The three shields at Mayo represent research, education, and patient care. Many staff members are actively involved in all three areas, making meaningful contributions to the medical community. A complimentary treat trolley occasionally visits units, offering candy and other sweets for staff to enjoy. Having Mayo Clinic on your résumé is a valuable career milestone, as it is recognized as one of the top hospitals in the world.
cons_text: The health insurance benefits could be more competitive given Mayo Clinic’s reputation. For example, there is no $0 deductible plan option, premiums remain relatively high, and employees must request their own insurance card directly from the insurance provider. Paid parental leave is currently limited to two weeks. The Minnesota paid parental leave program, which offers up to 20 weeks of paid maternity leave and 12 weeks of paid paternity leave, has not yet been fully implemented. Parking availability can be challenging, particularly during peak hours. Although Mayo states its compensation is competitive, salaries are determined by a strict scale based on years of experience in the profession. In some cases, this can result in significant pay reductions compared to prior roles, such as a $60,000 decrease in pay. There are no unions for nurses or other professions, and the organization actively works to maintain a non-unionized workforce.

Would get yelled at for sitting down for more than 30 seconds or using the bathroom during an 8-12 hour shift because the unit was so overworked. This was not an issue for every unit, but unfortunately was for the one I worked on. Additionally, safety of staff was neglected constantly and 'taking; physical abuse from patients was the 'norm', even when it was brought up to management, we would be reprimanded for this. Finally, the sick call-in policy also put patients and co workers at risk. Staff could not call in sick (with contagious diseases) if they already did a few times before in the year-- or they would be at risk of losing their job.

pros_text: Prestigious Institution: Internationally recognized for medical excellence and innovation, Mayo Clinic adds strong credibility to your CV. Access to Clinical Data: Unique opportunity to work with high-quality, de-identified patient data, especially beneficial for researchers in AI, imaging, or bioinformatics. Collaborative Environment: Interdisciplinary culture encourages collaboration between clinicians, scientists, and engineers. Strong Research Infrastructure: Robust support systems, including access to biostatistics, IRB assistance, research computing, and administrative support. Focus on Translational Impact: Projects are often clinically relevant and aimed at real-world implementation, which is rewarding for applied researchers. Internal Funding Opportunities: Postdocs can apply for intramural seed grants and are often encouraged to submit K99/R00 or equivalent career development awards. Excellent Work-Life Balance: Compared to other high-pressure research institutions, Mayo often promotes a healthier and more humane research culture.
cons_text: Limited Academic Networking: Rochester and Phoenix campuses can feel geographically isolated from larger academic ecosystems, which may limit seminar diversity or visiting speaker series. Variable PI Mentorship: Experience heavily depends on your mentor. Some labs offer strong guidance and career development; others are more hands-off. Transition to Faculty May Be Limited: Few internal postdocs are promoted directly to faculty roles; career progression often requires moving institutions. Bureaucracy: As a large healthcare organization, navigating institutional policies, compliance, and data access protocols can be slow and frustrating. Salary Considerations: While above NIH minimums, compensation may still lag behind tech industry roles or more competitive postdoc positions in industry-aligned labs.

cons_text: Joining this organization came with significant excitement. Its stellar reputation and compelling mission were incredibly appealing, and I even accepted a lower total compensation package, driven by the prospect of contributing to a positive societal impact. I truly believed I could make a difference here. However, my actual experience has been quite different from those initial hopes. I work within an area often described as a "platform," which initially seemed poised to be the future of healthcare, with the potential to dramatically improve patient outcomes. Unfortunately, this vision remains largely unrealized. Much of this can be attributed to the leadership at various levels, especially with the Mayo CEO and COO of my group. There's a palpable sense of internal pressure that often feels artificial, contributing to a generally difficult work environment. The organizational culture, at least within my domain, appears to be heavily influenced by fear, where deference to the COOs authority is often rewarded over contributions. Challenging the status quo, even when justified, will carry significant repercussions. This is particularly problematic when valid points are raised, as they can be perceived as threats by those in leadership positions. For example, there's a clear lack of strategic direction, evident in the sheer number of "priorities" that are simultaneously juggled – it's difficult to see how the 70th item on a list can genuinely be considered a priority. This highlights a significant disconnect in setting and executing clear objectives. While there are some talented individuals in leadership roles, it feels like many struggle to effectively manage upward when faced with less competent authority. Having worked in tech, I believe many of these leaders would be eaten up by standard directors at most tech companies. To focus a bit more on the COO, it's apparent to all that he has limited operational knowledge and seems to have achieved their position through aggressive interpersonal dynamics. He consistently undermines colleagues in public discussions. What follows is typically a frustrating cycle of criticism without any practical advice, leaving teams without a clear path forward. He is consistently proven wrong, but feels like he is either too dense to acknowledge he was wrong or has made a career of just continuing to belittle people in the hope they do not dare call him on it. Despite these challenges, there are truly exceptional individuals within the organization, particularly among the doctors working with the "platform." Interacting with the doctors has been inspiring, and their dedication is undeniable. My only observation is a desire for stronger advocacy from them against operational inefficiencies, especially concerning the COO, who lacks both relevant medical and technical expertise. Overall, I'm give this organization a 2-star rating. My respect for many of the individuals here, especially the medical professionals, and the inherent potential of the mission keep it from being a 1. However, for those in non-medical roles (or medical roles but devote most of their time to this team), the experience will be frustrating. There's a possibility for significant improvement, particularly with future leadership changes, but whether it's worth waiting to see that unfold, or joining before such changes occur, is a significant consideration.

pros_text: I love working for J&J for multiple reasons. I enjoy that J&J has adapted as a large company to the demands of a modern workforce while keeping some of the tried and true cultural elements of a mature company. For example, incredibly generous time off, instead of "unlimited PTO". Territories are not unusually large for field teams and they are growing their patient support options through acquisitions of patient support hubs. The different teams work hard to make sure folks in different functions are supported. Such as national contracts are in place quickly and we feel the results downstream on a local level, or we can reach out to people in different functions to have candid conversations about what isn't happening that we've been told to expect. There's a great amount of partnership that's possible if you're willing to reach out. That part of the company culture is great to be a part of.
cons_text: While the company has made huge strides by purchasing the PSC (Patient Service Center) and integrating the company's personnel as J&J employees, they are a sub par hub with training lapses. Many of the interactions I have with them lack accountability and professionalism. I think this hub would benefit from a different model and increased incentivization to perform at a higher level for patients. I worry what patients experience when relying on the PSC for information regarding their treatments and I often do not feel our hub counterparts are genuinely our partners who understand the responsibility they have to produce results for patients.

cons_text: Key focus areas include financial gain and short-term objectives, with a lack of emphasis on long-term strategies and insufficient expertise in discovery and development. The business model relies heavily on licensing agreements. Consequently, the organization undergoes frequent reorganizations and layoffs, and struggles with competency gaps. Management appointments are often influenced by personal connections rather than merit. Ineffective people management, limited experience, and a lack of management training programs and growth opportunities are also evident. pros_text: Prestigious Institution: Internationally recognized for medical excellence and innovation, Mayo Clinic adds strong credibility to your CV. Access to Clinical Data: Unique opportunity to work with high-quality, de-identified patient data, especially beneficial for researchers in AI, imaging, or bioinformatics. Collaborative Environment: Interdisciplinary culture encourages collaboration between clinicians, scientists, and engineers. Strong Research Infrastructure: Robust support systems, including access to biostatistics, IRB assistance, research computing, and administrative support. Focus on Translational Impact: Projects are often clinically relevant and aimed at real-world implementation, which is rewarding for applied researchers. Internal Funding Opportunities: Postdocs can apply for intramural seed grants and are often encouraged to submit K99/R00 or equivalent career development awards. Excellent Work-Life Balance: Compared to other high-pressure research institutions, Mayo often promotes a healthier and more humane research culture.
cons_text: Limited Academic Networking: Rochester and Phoenix campuses can feel geographically isolated from larger academic ecosystems, which may limit seminar diversity or visiting speaker series. Variable PI Mentorship: Experience heavily depends on your mentor. Some labs offer strong guidance and career development; others are more hands-off. Transition to Faculty May Be Limited: Few internal postdocs are promoted directly to faculty roles; career progression often requires moving institutions. Bureaucracy: As a large healthcare organization, navigating institutional policies, compliance, and data access protocols can be slow and frustrating. Salary Considerations: While above NIH minimums, compensation may still lag behind tech industry roles or more competitive postdoc positions in industry-aligned labs.

cons_text: Joining this organization came with significant excitement. Its stellar reputation and compelling mission were incredibly appealing, and I even accepted a lower total compensation package, driven by the prospect of contributing to a positive societal impact. I truly believed I could make a difference here. However, my actual experience has been quite different from those initial hopes. I work within an area often described as a "platform," which initially seemed poised to be the future of healthcare, with the potential to dramatically improve patient outcomes. Unfortunately, this vision remains largely unrealized. Much of this can be attributed to the leadership at various levels, especially with the Mayo CEO and COO of my group. There's a palpable sense of internal pressure that often feels artificial, contributing to a generally difficult work environment. The organizational culture, at least within my domain, appears to be heavily influenced by fear, where deference to the COOs authority is often rewarded over contributions. Challenging the status quo, even when justified, will carry significant repercussions. This is particularly problematic when valid points are raised, as they can be perceived as threats by those in leadership positions. For example, there's a clear lack of strategic direction, evident in the sheer number of "priorities" that are simultaneously juggled – it's difficult to see how the 70th item on a list can genuinely be considered a priority. This highlights a significant disconnect in setting and executing clear objectives. While there are some talented individuals in leadership roles, it feels like many struggle to effectively manage upward when faced with less competent authority. Having worked in tech, I believe many of these leaders would be eaten up by standard directors at most tech companies. To focus a bit more on the COO, it's apparent to all that he has limited operational knowledge and seems to have achieved their position through aggressive interpersonal dynamics. He consistently undermines colleagues in public discussions. What follows is typically a frustrating cycle of criticism without any practical advice, leaving teams without a clear path forward. He is consistently proven wrong, but feels like he is either too dense to acknowledge he was wrong or has made a career of just continuing to belittle people in the hope they do not dare call him on it. Despite these challenges, there are truly exceptional individuals within the organization, particularly among the doctors working with the "platform." Interacting with the doctors has been inspiring, and their dedication is undeniable. My only observation is a desire for stronger advocacy from them against operational inefficiencies, especially concerning the COO, who lacks both relevant medical and technical expertise. Overall, I'm give this organization a 2-star rating. My respect for many of the individuals here, especially the medical professionals, and the inherent potential of the mission keep it from being a 1. However, for those in non-medical roles (or medical roles but devote most of their time to this team), the experience will be frustrating. There's a possibility for significant improvement, particularly with future leadership changes, but whether it's worth waiting to see that unfold, or joining before such changes occur, is a significant consideration.

pros_text: Mayo Clinic is deeply committed to patient care. Everyone working here prioritizes the needs of the patient above all else. Team members across different roles treat each other with respect and professionalism. Staff parking is provided free of charge onsite. The three shields at Mayo represent research, education, and patient care. Many staff members are actively involved in all three areas, making meaningful contributions to the medical community. A complimentary treat trolley occasionally visits units, offering candy and other sweets for staff to enjoy. Having Mayo Clinic on your résumé is a valuable career milestone, as it is recognized as one of the top hospitals in the world.
cons_text: The health insurance benefits could be more competitive given Mayo Clinic’s reputation. For example, there is no $0 deductible plan option, premiums remain relatively high, and employees must request their own insurance card directly from the insurance provider. Paid parental leave is currently limited to two weeks. The Minnesota paid parental leave program, which offers up to 20 weeks of paid maternity leave and 12 weeks of paid paternity leave, has not yet been fully implemented. Parking availability can be challenging, particularly during peak hours. Although Mayo states its compensation is competitive, salaries are determined by a strict scale based on years of experience in the profession. In some cases, this can result in significant pay reductions compared to prior roles, such as a $60,000 decrease in pay. There are no unions for nurses or other professions, and the organization actively works to maintain a non-unionized workforce.
